Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I spent the whole evening preparing a session for the new hires, determined to share the tricks I’d learned over years on the site. As a mentor, I felt responsible for making sure they understood the safety protocols and the shortcuts that could save them hours. The project deadline was looming, and I knew this session could make a real difference. But the next morning, as I laced up my boots, I saw the notice: an optional training session next week, right in the middle of our busiest shift. As a laborer, I was expected to be on the ground, shoulder to shoulder with the crew, not off in a classroom. The foreman had made it clear—every hand was needed, no exceptions. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me. If I skipped the training, I’d be letting down the new guys who needed guidance. If I left the crew short-handed, I’d be breaking the trust of my team. My mind raced, torn between the urge to teach and the duty to build, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
